question.text: According to the Bohr model, what determines the shortest wavelength in a given series of wavelengths emitted by the atom?

options.text: The quantum number <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub></math> that identifies the higher energy level from which the electron falls into a lower energy level.

The quantum number <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi></msub></math> that identifies the lower energy level into which the electron falls from a higher energy level.

The ratio <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac bevelled="true"><msub><mi>n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi></msub><msub><mi>n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub></mfrac></math>, where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi></msub></math> is the quantum number that identifies the lower energy level into which the electron falls and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub></math> is the quantum number that identifies the higher level from which the electron falls.

The sum <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub></math> of two quantum numbers, where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi></msub></math> identifies the lower energy level into which the electron falls and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub></math> identifies the higher level from which the electron falls.

solution.text: The shortest wavelength <math> <mrow> <msub> <mi>λ</mi> <mtext>shortest</mtext> </msub> </mrow> </math> in a given series can be calculated <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msub><mi>λ</mi><mtext>shortest</mtext></msub></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><msup><mtext mathvariant="italic">RZ</mtext><mn>2</mn></msup><msubsup><mtext mathvariant="italic">n</mtext><mtext>f</mtext><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mfrac></math>, where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>R</mi></math> is the Rydberg constant and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Z</mi></math> is the number of protons in the nucleus.
